I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), including microenterprises in rural areas, 
constitute a vast portion of Cambodia’s real economy in terms of the number of firms (99%) and 
employment (45%). Recognizing the importance of SMEs, the Government of Cambodia (the 
Government) emphasizes their potential to increase investment, generate employment, and 
reduce poverty. The Government therefore requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
assist in SME development.1 Accordingly, the Cambodia SME Development Program (CSDP), 
approved in 2004, aims to prompt institutional reforms to support the development of SMEs.2  
 
2.  As outlined in the design and monitoring framework in Appendix 1, technical assistance 
(TA) aims to support CSDP implementation, particularly concerning the third tranche release 
policy conditions. It also aims to continue ADB’s support for capacity-development efforts by the 
Government and aid coordination related to the SME sector. The Fact-Finding Mission fielded in 
October 2005 reached an understanding with the Government on the purpose, approach, and 
implementation arrangements of TA.3  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Cambodian SMEs face a number of significant challenges, among them governance and 
regulatory reform. A key challenge is to create an enabling business environment that minimizes 
the risks and costs of doing business, which in turn offers better protection of property rights and 
opens  up  the  scope  of  opportunities  for  entrepreneurs.  Creating  a  conducive  business 
environment requires addressing problems related to missing or poorly functioning institutional, 
legal, and regulatory structures that impair the larger part of the Cambodian economy, SMEs. 
The  following  paragraphs  discuss  the  major  challenges  that  SMEs  face,  achievements  of 
current CSDP implementation, and remaining tasks.4  
 
4.  Limited Capacity for Implementing the SME Development Framework. In July 2005, 
as part of the CSDP second tranche, the Government issued for the first time a comprehensive 
policy strategy for SME development—the SME Development Framework (SMEDF). To support 
implementation, the Government established the SME subcommittee and its secretariat office.5 
The subcommittee prepares an annual report on the status of the SME sector and continuously 
reviews the SMEDF. While the adoption of the SMEDF marks significant progress for policy 
coordination  and  institution  building,  implementing  its  action  plan  still  faces  considerable 
challenges.  Furthermore,  although  the  SME  subcommittee  should  promote  interagency 
coordination, considerable support is needed to enhance the capacity of the subcommittee and 
its secretariat to undertake the necessary tasks.  Furthermore, improving data collection on 
SMEs will require work with the Ministry of Planning’s National Institute of Statistics (NIS). NIS

needs capacity development to support data gathering useful to developing SME policies. In 
addition, ADB needs to continue being proactive in facilitating aid coordination and consultation, 
following a request by the Government for ADB to serve as the focal donor agency for SME 
development. Finally, effective monitoring is necessary to ensure continuous evaluation of the 
SMEDF.  
 
5.  Barriers to Effective Business Registration. Business registration reform is deemed 
necessary in Cambodia. Many Cambodian SMEs are not registered and operate informally 
because of red tape and the high cost of registration. To meet CSDP first and second tranche 
policy conditions, the Ministry of Commerce (MOC) introduced measures to simplify the process 
and significantly reduce costs. The average number of companies registering each month has 
doubled  since  the  reforms  were  implemented  in  September  2004.  To  further  improve  the 
registration process, MOC needs significant technical support and capacity development to (i) 
decentralize the registration process (currently, enterprises can register only at the MOC office 
in Phnom Penh); (ii) develop an information technology (IT)-based system allowing MOC to 
maintain and update the records of registered enterprises; and (iii) reaffirm the reforms by 
refining the legal framework and engaging in publicity campaigns. 
 
6.  Lack of Capacity to Implement Business Licensing Reform. Many studies carried 
out in Cambodia have identified opaque and complicated procedures for obtaining licenses and 
the heavy burden of inspections as major obstacles in the business environment, resulting in 
excessive costs for entrepreneurs. A number of case studies indicate that a typical SME in 
Cambodia may have to pay about $1,500 in formal and informal fees, without clear justification 
for the licensing requirements or any predictability of its cost. This clearly illustrates the need for 
transparency, good governance, and administrative efficiency to promote SME development. 
Currently,  as  part  of  the  CSDP  second  tranche  conditions,  ADB  is  helping  the  SME 
subcommittee develop an overall framework for business licensing reform. As a comprehensive 
licensing  reform  plan  is  expected  to  be  approved  by  the  Government  in  May  2006,  the 
secretariat will require significant capacity development to ensure that the plan, which includes 
establishing a one-stop information window on business licenses, is effectively implemented. 
The subcommittee will need to continue reviewing numerous licenses and begin the process of 
building capacity at relevant ministries to enable them to carry out in the future their own 
regulatory impact assessments, which estimate the economic and financial costs and benefits of 
regulations.  
7.  Limited Capacity for Implementing Accounting and Taxation Reforms. Studies on 
financing SMEs in Cambodia found that the quality and availability of financial information on 
SME borrowers ranges from minimally acceptable to wholly nonexistent. One of the reasons for 
this  lack  of  financial  information  is  that  SMEs  are  generally  unable  to  prepare  financial 
statements and provide information relevant to the needs of lenders. As per the CSDP second 
tranche, ADB has been helping the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) and private sector 
representatives develop a set of simplified financial reporting guidelines for SMEs, as current 
Cambodian  accounting  standards  are  deemed  to  be  overly  complicated  for  most  small 
enterprises. However, even if the simplified guidelines are completed and issued by the relevant 
authorities, support is needed to effectively raise awareness among SMEs and train accounting 
professionals.  
8.  Absence of Legal and Institutional Framework for Leasing. One major obstacle to 
SMEs is the almost complete lack of access to medium- and long-term financing. Leasing offers 
an alternative form of finance, which relies more on the cash flow of SMEs than on collateral. 
Per the CSDP second tranche, ADB has been helping the Government, mainly the National

3
Bank of Cambodia (NBC), to draft a law on leasing and so establish the necessary legal 
framework. This complements other supportive infrastructure, such as the draft law on secured 
transactions,  being  developed  in  Cambodia.  However,  considerable  support  is  needed  to 
ensure  that  all  related  implementing  regulations  are  in  place  and  effectively  implemented. 
Capacity development and dissemination is required to support industry’s development.  
 
9.  Capacity Development to Operate and Expand the Credit Information System. The 
lack  of  reliable  borrower  credit  information  is  a  major  contributor  to  the  high-risk  lending 
environment in Cambodia.  Per the CSDP second tranche, ADB has been working with NBC 
and the Association of Bankers in Cambodia (ABC) to develop, on a pilot basis, a web-based 
credit information system. NBC is also preparing a new prakas (regulation issued by a line 
ministry) to provide the necessary legal framework for a credit information system. Furthermore, 
participating banks, ABC, and NBC are preparing a code of conduct outlining the rights and 
responsibilities of members. Despite these efforts to build the governance structure of the credit 
information system, success ultimately depends on its swift implementation and the effective 
functioning of the system from the outset. Considerable technical guidance is necessary to 
ensure that the system is effectively administered and efficiently utilized by participating banks 
and that the code of conduct is implemented, ensuring system integrity.   
 
III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  As stated above, the major objective of the CSDP is to assist the Government in 
creating a regulatory environment conducive to SME development. This will be achieved by 
helping the Government to effectively implement the SMEDF and CSDP. In addressing the 
main issues identified above, TA will provide (i) technical support, (ii) capacity development, (iii) 
support  for  consensus  building  and  aid  coordination,  and  (iv)  evaluation  of  the  current 
achievements. The major outcomes are outlined below. 
 
11.  Supporting SMEDF Implementation. As the SMEDF was approved in July 2005, the 
SME subcommittee and secretariat will need to review and possibly update it by the end of 2006. 
They will also need continued support to assist in coordinating the activities of stakeholders 
involved in implementing the SMEDF. Improving data collection on SMEs will require working 
with NIS. Collecting relevant data is critical to evaluating the performance of the SMEDF. A 
specific set of monitorable indicators will be developed and tested through available data and 
field surveys. Accordingly, TA should develop NIS’s capacity for data gathering. TA should also 
help the SME secretariat improve dissemination of relevant information to SMEs through its 
portal  site  and  other  means.  Further,  TA  will  analyze  the  commercial  legal  framework  for 
Cambodia,  particularly  with  regard  to  property  rights  and  commercial  arbitration,  which  is 
emphasized in the SMEDF. Finally, TA, in conjunction with other donor agencies, will develop 
specific action plans to ensure that the reforms as stipulated in the SMEDF and CSDP have 
impact locally and provincially as well.   
12.  Strengthening  Business  Registration  Reform.  Based  on  the  reforms  undertaken 
during 2004–2005, three major tasks for reforming business registration are anticipated for 
2006. The first challenge will be to complete the implementation of reforms to registration 
procedures  and  fees  that  are  outlined  in  MOC’s  time-bound  plan,  by  issuing  relevant 
implementing regulations. The second challenge will be to expand the role of IT in the company 
registration  process  according  to  a  time-bound  plan.  MOC  also  needs  to  issue  a  prakas 
establishing a system for online exchange of registration data between Phnom Penh and the

4     
provinces. The third major challenge for 2006 will be to implement decentralization reforms. 
These should be rolled out in one or more pilot provinces, allowing companies to register with 
the provincial department of commerce. This process will be consistent with the Government’s 
Strategic Framework for Decentralization and Deconcentration.  
 
13.  Initiating  Business  Licensing  Reform.  Sustainable  licensing  reform  requires 
establishing an administrative recourse mechanism. In 2006, it will be necessary to implement 
the recourse mechanism provided for in the regulatory review plan, a process that will require 
capacity building. The CSDP and SMEDF also provide for Government approval of the design 
of a one-stop information window dispensing relevant information and guidelines on licensing 
and  inspection.  The  SME  subcommittee  and  secretariat  will  need  technical  assistance  for 
developing the legal requirements, business processes and IT necessary to develop the window.  
This requires placing emphasis on the Government’s enforcement capacity and bureaucratic 
accountability 
14.  Implementing Accounting and Taxation Guidelines for SMEs. Although a simplified 
financial reporting template is expected to be issued by early 2006, some concern remains that 
not  all  SMEs,  particularly  the  smaller  enterprises,  will  be  able  to  complete  the  template. 
Accordingly, the need exists to build the capacity of accountants with the knowledge and skill to 
prepare financial statements for SMEs. A thorough study of the capacity of local institutions to 
provide  technical  training  courses  will  be  undertaken,  and  a  concrete  action  plan  for 
strengthening accounting curricula proposed. Secondly, TA will identify specific ways to support 
the capacity of accounting professionals, including support for educating future accountants. 
Finally, TA will include a detailed study of ways to improve the current taxation system, in 
conjunction with other relevant donor agencies, particularly the International Monetary Fund.  
 
15.  Expanding  the  Credit  Information  System.  Once the credit information system is 
operational, TA will support its operations and further development, including developing user 
manuals and providing extensive training to participating banks on how to use the system. In 
conjunction with NBC and ABC, TA will continue to review existing legislation with the purpose 
of developing an enabling legal framework. TA will also develop a detailed action plan for 
expanding the credit information system, based on the lessons learned from the experience of 
the pilot system. Finally, as the credit information system, however important it may be, is only 
one  pillar  of  a  developed  banking  industry  that  uses  IT  to  enhance  its  effectiveness  and 
efficiency,  banks  will  require  other  important  IT-reliant  institutional  underpinnings.  TA  will 
analyze IT needs for a more efficient banking sector.  
  
16.  Promoting  Leasing  Development.  Leasing  continues  to  be  virtually  unknown  in 
Cambodia as a financial product. To address this, TA will attempt to make finance leasing an 
attractive product in Cambodia. Firstly, TA will support, in consultation with the NBC and MOC, 
completion of the leasing law and make recommendations for implementing it. Secondly, TA will 
liaise with the Tax Department to examine ambiguities in the Law on Taxation that affect the 
leasing environment and make recommendations for clarifying them. Thirdly, TA will provide 
capacity  development  to  support  enhancing  technical  skills  through  training  programs  for 
Government officers, bankers, and SMEs. Finally, TA will hold frequent discussions with the 
private sector to further identify ways to promote the development of the leasing industry in 
Cambodia.

5
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
17.  TA will fund consultants with expertise in the areas identified for implementing reforms. 
The team of consultants will conduct in-depth consultations with the Government and private 
sector stakeholders. Consultations will be part of the process to produce targeted outputs and 
will  be  followed  by  a  number  of  roundtable  discussions  and  workshops  to  transfer  the 
knowledge and skills all stakeholders need to implement the policy conditions under the CSDP 
and SMEDF. ADB will monitor the process closely to ensure the quality of outputs and training. 
In addition to the technical inputs, TA will support the Government’s capacity development to 
ensure that reforms are sustainable.  
 
18.  The consultants will prepare a detailed work plan before the start of services, which will 
include a timetable for deliverables defined under each component of TA. They will be required 
to submit interim reports meeting deadlines specified in the work plan agreed with ADB. All 
reports will be reviewed by the Government and ADB. Tripartite meetings will be held before 
finalizing the draft reports. The final report, incorporating comments from the Government and 
ADB, will be submitted upon completion of service.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  TA is estimated to cost $950,000 equivalent. The Government has requested ADB to 
finance $800,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding 
program.  The  Government  will  finance  the  remaining  $150,000  equivalent  by  providing 
counterpart  staff,  office  space,  administrative  services,  and  physical  facilities.  The  cost 
estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 3.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  To facilitate TA implementation, ADB has requested that the CSDP steering committee 
remain to oversee implementation. The committee is headed by the head of the Ministry of 
Industry, Mines, and Energy, the Executing Agency. The implementing agencies include MEF, 
NBC, MOC, and Ministry of Planning. TA will be implemented over 13 months, from May 2006 
to  May  2007  and  require  seven  international  consultants  for  27  person-months  and  eight 
domestic consultants for 44 person-months. The consultant team will produce an inception 
report, two interim reports, and a draft final report—each report to be discussed in tripartite 
meetings.  
 
21.  Due to the diverse skill requirements of TA, consultants will be recruited as individuals in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for the selection and engagement of domestic consultants. Procurement 
under TA will be in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines. The equipment to be 
purchased under TA includes computer and other office equipment, which, upon TA completion, 
will be disposed of according to ADB guidelines. Outline terms of reference are provided in 
Appendix 4.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Cambodia for Capacity Building for SME Development – Phase II, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 4 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The terms of reference stipulate that the work plan is subject to refinement by the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). The work plan of the domestic consultants may also be refined, based 
on the needs of the team leader throughout TA implementation. Further, all team members will (i) 
assist ADB missions with the related activities, as well as conduct discussions and workshops with 
the relevant stakeholders, to build consensus on the CSDP framework, particularly at the local 
level, as appropriate, and (ii) provide any appropriate technical inputs required for the updated 
SMEDF.  The person-months may be provided intermittently, based on agreement between the 
consultants, the Government, and ADB.  
 
A.  International Consultants 
2.  All  international  consultants  will  (i)  have  extensive  working  knowledge  of  small-  and 
medium-sized  enterprise  (SME)  development  (particularly  on  business  regulations),  its  policy 
framework, and applicable international experience and (ii) demonstrate good understanding of the 
history  and  development  of  the  Cambodian  SME  sector  and  the  development  stage  of  the 
country’s legal and regulatory system under which the SMEs operate, including promotion policies, 
legal reforms, and capacity-building measures for SMEs. 
  
3.  International Business Registration and Licensing Specialist/Team Leader (7 person-
months). The team leader will (i) be responsible for all outputs of TA, including compiling all the 
required reports, and (ii) provide necessary guidance to and coordination of all other consultants. 
Tasks and responsibilities include the following activities: 
(i)  Assist the SME secretariat with implementing the business licensing reform plan.  
(ii)  Prepare a detailed action plan to implement a recourse mechanism and assist in its 
implementation  as  required  or  appropriate,  with  emphasis  placed  on  the 
Government’s enforcement capacity and bureaucratic accountability. 
(iii)  Prepare a detailed action plan to implement a one-stop window for licenses and 
assist in its implementation as required or appropriate. 
(iv)  Assist the Ministry of Commerce with implementing the business registration reform 
plan, including decentralization of registration. 
(v)  Design a plan to collect monitorable data and indicators related to the impact of the 
CSDP  (per  the  program  framework  of  the  CSDP)  and  analyze  the  impact  as 
required.  
 
4.  International SME Specialist/Deputy Team Leader (5 person-months). The deputy team 
leader  will  be  responsible  for  administering  consolidated  equipment  purchases.  Tasks  and 
responsibilities include the following: 
(i)  Assist the SME subcommittee and secretariat in preparing an update of the SME 
Development Framework (SMEDF) that assesses progress in its implementation 
and identifies further actions to be taken to support SMEs. 
(ii)  Draft a detailed action plan for coordination of the SME sector, in close consultation 
with the SME subcommittee and the ADB Cambodia Resident Mission.  
(iii)  Support the SME subcommittee and secretariat in coordination activities related to 
implementing the SMEDF. 
(iv)  Prepare  a  detailed  implementation  plan  for  the  National  Institute  of  Statistics’ 
collection of data, disaggregated by gender, on SMEs and enterprises. 
(v)  Help  the  SME  secretariat  develop  a  plan  to  improve  information  dissemination 
relevant to SMEs.

Appendix 4  11 
5.  International Leasing Specialist (3 person-months). The specialist will have extensive 
working knowledge of leasing, in terms of market and industry development as well as legal 
frameworks,  and  applicable  international  experience.  Tasks  and  responsibilities  include  the 
following: 
(i)  In  consultation  with  NBC  and  other  relevant  stakeholders,  draft  the  necessary 
implementing guidelines of the law on leasing applicable to financial leasing, which 
may also include provisions required for taxation and other related issues.  
(ii)  Design and implement a comprehensive capacity-building and training program for 
the Government and other relevant institutions.  
(iii)  Draft a detailed analysis and action plan on specific measures to further promote the 
leasing industry in Cambodia, including micro-leasing, in consultation with public 
and private stakeholders.  
(iv)  Provide any appropriate technical inputs required for the updated SMEDF. 
(v)  Hold workshops and other dissemination events to inform stakeholders and raise 
public awareness of leasing. 
 
6.  International Accounting Specialist (3 person-months). The specialist will have extensive 
working knowledge of international accounting and taxation practices and applicable international 
experience. Tasks and responsibilities include the following: 
(i)  Design  a  training  program  for  SMEs  (to  be  executed  mostly  by  the  domestic 
accounting specialist) aimed at raising awareness in the most effective targeted 
group of the need to develop accounting capabilities, and oversee the training 
activities of the domestic accounting specialist.  
(ii)  Working  with  the  leasing  specialist  and  team  leader,  develop  an  accounting 
standard for the leasing industry based on International Accounting Standard 17.  
(iii)  Working  with  various  institutions,  conduct  a  detailed  diagnostic  analysis  of  the 
taxation system in Cambodia.  
(iv)  Provide any appropriate technical inputs required for the updated SMEDF. 
(v)  Help  the  Ministry  of  Economy  and  Finance  modify  regulations  as  required  for 
developing the leasing industry. 
 
7.  International Credit Information Specialist (3 person-months). The specialist will have 
extensive working knowledge of credit information, in terms of operational needs as well as legal 
frameworks,  and  applicable  international  experience.  Tasks  and  responsibilities  include  the 
following: 
(i)  Identify and resolve problems experienced during the initial operation period of 
credit information system.  
(ii)  Develop the framework of the credit information system annual report.  
(iii)  Propose a plan for expanding the credit information system to cover positive credit 
information such as outstanding loan information.  
(iv)  Conduct a detailed analysis of the information technology (IT) requirements of the 
banking sector. 
(v)  Provide any appropriate technical inputs required for the updated SMEDF. 
 
8.  International Regulatory Specialist (2 person-months). The specialist will have extensive 
working knowledge of credit information, in terms of operational needs as well as legal frameworks, 
and applicable international experience. Tasks and responsibilities include the following: 
(i)  Provide legal and regulatory input on business licensing and registration reforms, 
including drafting legal documents. 
(ii)  Draft a long-term plan for comprehensive regulatory reform in Cambodia, the outline 
of which needs to be agreeb by the Government and ADB.

12  Appendix 4   
 
9.  Commercial Law Specialist (4 person-months). The specialist will have extensive working 
knowledge of commercial laws, in terms of academic and professional background, and applicable 
international experience. Tasks and responsibilities include the following: 
(i)  Conduct a general overview of the commercial legal framework in Cambodia as an 
input for the updated SMEDF.  
(ii)  Identify measures for institutional development of the legal and judicial system in 
Cambodia,  including  commercial  arbitration,  with  a  specific  focus  on  improving 
property rights and contracts for commercial transactions.  
(iii)  Draft an in-depth assessment of laws covering (a) secured transactions, (b) tax, and 
(c) banking and financial institutions, and reconcile the needed reforms for effective 
synchronization with the draft leasing law.  
(iv)  Identify any other laws pertinent to the draft leasing law. 
(v)  Assess the commercial enterprise law and related legal documents as needed to 
advance business registration and licenses reform. 
 
B.  Domestic Consultants 
10.  All domestic consultants should (i) have a background in SME development, (ii) understand 
private  sector  development,  (iii)  have  experience  working  with  international  consultants  and 
governments, (iv) be proficient in English, and (v) provide inputs related to the program framework.  
 
11.  The domestic consultants are responsible for the following: (i) under the guidance of the 
team leader, collect and analyze required information and data and make them available in English, 
in an organized, readable form and (ii) conduct research on specific topics as required by the team 
leader.  
 
12.  Domestic SME Development Specialist/Domestic Team Leader (7 person-months). The 
domestic team leader is to provide inputs for issues related to implementing the SMEDF, including 
legal reforms pertaining to licensing reforms. Tasks and responsibilities include the following: 
(i)  Help the international team leader with all aspects of his or her tasks in the terms of 
reference related to (a) the SMEDF and (b) business licensing reform. 
(ii)  Arrange and organize discussions and workshops, and assist the team leader in 
preparing  materials  for  them,  including  translating  documents  and  interpreting 
during discussions. 
 
13.  Domestic Business Registration Specialist (6 person-months). The domestic business 
registration specialist is to provide inputs related to IT development in (i) the business registration 
system and (ii) the SME information system. Tasks and responsibilities include the following: 
(i)  Help  the  team  leader  support  decentralizing  business  registration,  including 
performing capacity development activities as required. 
(ii)  Arrange and organize discussions and workshops, and assist the team leader in 
preparing  materials  for  them,  including  translating  documents  and  interpreting 
during discussions. 
 
14.  Domestic IT Specialist (5 person-months). The domestic IT specialist is to provide inputs 
related to IT development in (i) the business registration system and (ii) the SME information 
system. Tasks and responsibilities include the following: 
(i)  Assist the team leader and the international business registration specialist in all 
aspects of their tasks in the terms of reference related to (a) business registration

Appendix 4  13 
reform,  (b)  the  credit  information  system,  and  (c)  the  SME  information  portal, 
particularly regarding IT components. 
(ii)  Arrange and organize discussions and workshops, and assist the team leader in 
preparing  materials  for  them,  including  translating  documents  and  interpreting 
during discussions. 
 
15.  Domestic SME Survey Specialist (2 person-months). The domestic SME survey specialist 
is  to  provide  inputs  related  to  evaluating  and  reviewing  the  CSDP  and  SMEDF.  Tasks  and 
responsibilities include the following: 
(i)  Conduct the survey, as designed by the team leader, on monitorable indicators and 
data regarding CSDP and SMEDF impact, coordinating with the relevant donor 
agencies as required.  
(ii)  Identify specific measures to support the Government’s conducting of such surveys 
annually. 
(iii)  Arrange and organize discussions and workshops, and assist the team leader in 
preparing  materials  for  them,  including  translating  documents  and  interpreting 
during discussions. 
 
16.  Domestic Regulatory Specialist (2 person-months). The domestic regulatory specialist is 
to provide inputs related to regulatory reform in Cambodia. Tasks and responsibilities include the 
following: 
(i)  Assist in drafting a long-term plan for comprehensive regulatory reform in Cambodia. 
(ii)  Arrange and organize discussions and workshops, and assist the team leader in 
preparing  materials  for  them,  including  translating  documents  and  interpreting 
during discussions. 
 
17.  Domestic Financial Specialist (6 person-months). The domestic financial specialist is to 
provide inputs related to developing the leasing industry and the required legal framework and 
must  have  experience  working  with  international  consultants  and  governments.  Tasks  and 
responsibilities include the following: 
(i)  Assist the team leader and the international leasing specialist in all aspects of their 
tasks in the terms of reference related to developing the legal framework on leasing, 
particularly  regarding  components  related  to  the  implementing  regulations  and 
taxation. 
(ii)  Arrange and organize discussions and workshops, and assist the team leader in 
preparing  materials  for  them,  including  translating  documents  and  interpreting 
during discussions. 
 
18.  Domestic Accounting Specialist (10 person-months). The domestic accounting specialist 
is to provide inputs related to leasing and accounting/taxation systems and must have experience 
working with international consultants and governments. Tasks and responsibilities include the 
following: 
(i)  Assist the team leader and the international accounting specialist in all aspects of 
their tasks in the terms of reference related to training SMEs in accounting. 
(ii)  Arrange and organize discussions and workshops, and assist the team leader in 
preparing  materials  for  them,  including  translating  documents  and  interpreting 
during discussions. 
 
19.  Domestic  Credit  Information  Specialist  (6  person-months).  The  domestic  credit 
information specialist is to provide inputs related to IT development in the credit information system. 
Tasks and responsibilities include the following:

14  Appendix 4   
(i)  Assist  the  team  leader  and  the  international  credit  information  specialist  in  all 
aspects of their tasks in the terms of reference related to implementing the credit 
information,  and  particularly  supporting  the  capacity  development  efforts  of 
participating banks as well as the necessary maintenance of the credit information 
system. 
(ii)  Arrange and organize discussions and workshops, and assist the team leader in 
preparing  materials  for  them,  including  translating  documents  and  interpreting 
during discussions. 
 
C.  Arrangements and Schedule 
20.  TA is scheduled to start on 30 May 2006 and will produce five draft reports, all conforming 
to ADB format. 
(i)  The first report, due by 30 June 2006, will provide a comprehensive outline of TA 
based on these terms of reference and initial discussions with the Government and 
ADB. 
(ii)  The second report, due by 30 September 2006, will be a revision of the first report 
based on comments received from the Government and ADB.  
(iii)  The third report, due by 30 January 2007, will aim to build consensus among 
stakeholders. 
(iv)  A draft final report, due by 30 March 2007, will be revised based upon comments by 
ADB and the Government.  
(v)  The final report is due by 30 May 2007.  
 
21.  Extensive  consultations  and  workshops  with  stakeholders,  including  local  and  central 
government officials and external agencies, are envisioned in the process of finalizing TA. The 
consultants are to hold at least 5 workshops before delivering the final report, including one at TA 
inception to clarify the consultants’ work plan and build consensus.
